awd_titl_txt: Precision Measurements with the CHIP-TRAP Mass Spectrometer for Tests of Special Relativity
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to perform a very precise measurement of mass difference between two types of chlorine atoms:  Chlorine-35 and Chlorine-36. These two isotopes have the same number of protons and electrons, so they have the same chemical properties, but chlorine-36 has one extra neutron, so they do not have the same mass. However, the mass difference is not simply the mass of the neutron. This is because, according to Einstein's famous equation, E = mc2, some of the mass of the extra neutron is given up as nuclear binding energy. Hence, by measuring the mass difference between chlorine-35 and chlorine-36, and accounting for the mass of the neutron, the chlorine-36 neutron binding energy can be determined. The mass difference measurement gives the right hand side of Einstein's equation and can be compared with other, independent measurements of the neutron binding energy that give the left hand side of Einstein's equation. These other measurements use precise spectroscopy techniques to measure the energy of gamma-rays (high energy electromagnetic radiation similar to x-rays) that are emitted just after a chlorine-35 nucleus captures a neutron to become chlorine-36 and releases the excess energy. The comparison of the mass difference and gamma ray energies then provides a direct test of E = mc2. 

This project will use high-precision Penning trap mass spectrometry to determine the mass difference between chlorine-35 and chlorine-36 by measuring the ratio of cyclotron frequencies of singly-charged ions containing these isotopes in the 12 Tesla magnetic field of the Central Michigan University High Precision Penning Trap (CHIP-TRAP). The cyclotron frequency will be determined using the image charge detection technique in which the image currents induced in the trap electrodes by the oscillating ion are detected and amplified with low noise cryogenic circuits. CHIP-TRAP will consist of a novel, double measurement trap structure that will enable the two ions whose mass ratio is to be determined to be simultaneously stored for long measurement times. Ultimately, the cyclotron frequency measurement for the two ions will be performed simultaneously, greatly reducing the effect of temporal magnetic field fluctuations. This technique should enable a precision in the mass ratio of 10 parts per trillion or less to be reached. Ions will be produced outside of the Penning trap using either a laser ablation ion source or a plasma ion source, and will be transported to a capture trap before being transferred to the precision measurement traps. This will reduce the amount of the long-lived (300,000 year half-life) chlorine isotope required for the experiment.

por.por_cntn:
This project aimed to perform a test of Einstein's famous equation E = mc2. To do this, the energy, E, released when an isotope of chlorine (35Cl) captured a neutron to become 36Cl, is to be compared with the mass difference, m, times c2 between 36Cl and 35Cl plus the mass of the neutron. The energy released has already been precisely measured using gamma-ray spectroscopy to a precision of about 5 eV. Our goal was to measure the 35Cl - 36Cl mass difference to a similar precision (the mass of the neutron is already known well enough).

To perform this measurement, we aimed to use a technique in which ions are confined with magnetic and electric fields in a so-called Penning trap, and their motional frequencies inside the trap are measured. The frequency can then be used to obtain the mass of the atoms. To perform this measurement, which requires high precision and the use of the radioactive isotope 36Cl, we are developing a new Penning trap mass spectrometer called CHIP-TRAP at Central Michigan University. 

Towards meeting the goals of this project we have continued the development of CHIP-TRAP. This has involved the commissioning of a laser ion source that was used to investigate the production of Cl+ ions. This study showed that it was not possible to produce Cl+ ions in this way (from NaCl ablated by the laser). We also designed and developed a new, novel ion source based on the Penning Ion Gauge source. This Penning Ion Trap source can produce pulses of ions in short duration, relatively low ion count bursts (~few hundred ions). We have fully characterized this source using inert gases and will next test it to produce Cl+ ions.

As part of this research project, we have also designed and fabricated a Multi-Reflection Time-of-Flight mass separator (MR-TOF-MS) that will be installed in the CHIP-TRAP apparatus and will enable improved selection of ions to be sent to the Penning trap for measurements. The MR-TOF-MS works by reflecting ions back and forth in an electrostatic trap such that ions of different mass move at different speeds and become spacially separated so that they can be isolated.

Finally, we have installed the CHIP-TRAP Penning traps in the 12 tesla magnet and performed the first tests to trap and detect ions. 

Intellectual Merit

The work performed during the course of this project has made progress towards the implementation of a new Penning trap mass spectrometer that will enable high precision measurements like the 36Cl - 35Cl mass difference measurement for a test if E = mc2, but also a wide range of mass measurements on long-lived and stables isotopes for applications in atomic and nuclear physics and beyond.

A key outcome of this project is development of a new ion source - the Penning Ion Trap source. This ion source could have applications in other fields that require a low emittance, short duration pulsed ion beam.

Broader Impacts

This project has supported one graduate student during the second year of his terminal M.S. degree and for two years of his Ph.D. degree. It has also supported one CMU undergraduate student to work part time during the school year and full-time during the summer, providing valuable research experience for this student who continued on to study for his physics Ph.D. at another institution. Finally, the award also supported an MPhys visiting student from the University of Surrey, UK to visit CMU for 10 months to perform research. By highlighting interesting topics, like testing E = mc2, this project helps to attract the attention of prospective students and the general public and encourages them to study and appreciate fundamental research in physics.
